skill.name: commit
skill.description: Create commit messages following Sentry conventions. Use when committing code changes, writing commit messages, or formatting git history. Follows conventional commits with Sentry-specific issue references.
skill.summary: Generate standardized commit messages following Sentry engineering practices and conventional commits format.
skill.author: davila7

security_audit.summary: This is a documentation-only skill providing commit message conventions. All 37 static findings are false positives: backtick patterns are markdown code blocks, URL fields are legitimate metadata, and C2/crypto alerts are keyword false positives from commit terminology. No executable code, network operations, or cryptographic functionality exists.

content.value_statement: Developers spend time crafting clear commit messages that follow team conventions. This skill generates standardized commit messages following Sentry engineering practices and conventional commits format with proper issue references.
actual_capabilities: Generate commit messages following Sentry conventional commits format
Create properly scoped commit headers with type and optional scope
Format commit bodies using imperative mood and present tense
Add appropriate issue references in footers (Fixes, Refs with multiple formats)
limitations: Does not execute git commands or modify repositories
Does not access git history or staged changes
Does not validate that commit follows all project-specific rules
Does not integrate with CI/CD systems

use_cases.title: Writing clear bug fix commits
use_cases.description: Generate descriptive fix commits that explain what was broken and how it was fixed, with proper issue references.

use_cases.title: Documenting feature development
use_cases.description: Create feature commits with appropriate scope and breaking change documentation for new functionality.

use_cases.title: Maintaining consistent commit history
use_cases.description: Enforce team conventions across a repository by generating standardized commit messages for all changes.

prompt_templates.title: Basic bug fix
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a commit message for fixing a null pointer exception in the user API endpoint. The fix adds a null check before accessing user properties. Reference issue SENTRY-5678.
prompt_templates.scenario: Creating a fix commit with issue reference

prompt_templates.title: Feature with scope
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a commit message for adding Slack thread replies for alert updates. The change posts replies to original threads instead of creating new messages. Reference issue GH-1234.
prompt_templates.scenario: Creating a feature commit with external issue reference

prompt_templates.title: Breaking change
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a commit message for removing deprecated v1 API endpoints. This is a breaking change that requires client migration to v2. Reference issue SENTRY-9999.
prompt_templates.scenario: Documenting a breaking change with migration requirements

prompt_templates.title: Refactoring commit
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a commit message for extracting common validation logic from three endpoints into a shared validator module. No behavior change.

output_examples.input: Generate a commit message for fixing a null response crash in the user API endpoint by adding a null check. Reference SENTRY-5678.
output_examples.output:
fix(api): Handle null response in user endpoint

The user API could return null for deleted accounts, causing a crash in the dashboard. Add null check before accessing user properties.

Fixes SENTRY-5678

output_examples.input: Generate a commit message for adding Slack thread replies for alert updates. Reference GH-1234.
output_examples.output:
feat(alerts): Add Slack thread replies for alert updates

When an alert is updated or resolved, post a reply to the original Slack thread instead of creating a new message. This keeps related notifications grouped together.

Refs GH-1234

output_examples.input: Generate a commit message for removing deprecated v1 endpoints as a breaking change. Reference SENTRY-9999.
output_examples.output:
feat(api)!: Remove deprecated v1 endpoints

Remove all v1 API endpoints that were deprecated in version 23.1. Clients should migrate to v2 endpoints.

BREAKING CHANGE: v1 endpoints no longer available
Fixes SENTRY-9999

best_practices: Use imperative mood in subject lines: Add feature not Added feature
Explain what and why in body, not how implementation works
Reference issues appropriately: Fixes to close, Refs to link
anti_patterns: Using past tense in subject lines: Added feature instead of Add feature
Exceeding 70 characters in subject line or 100 in total line length
Omitting issue references when changes relate to tracked work

faq.question: What is the Sentry commit format?
faq.answer: Sentry uses conventional commits with format: type(scope): subject, followed by optional body and footer with issue references. The header is required and scope is optional.

faq.question: When should I use Fixes versus Refs?
faq.answer: Use Fixes when the commit should close or resolve the issue when merged. Use Refs to link the commit to related issues without closing them.

faq.question: What commit types are supported?
faq.answer: Supported types include feat, fix, ref, perf, docs, test, build, ci, chore, style, meta, and license.

faq.question: Does this skill run git commands?
faq.answer: No, this skill only generates commit message text. It does not execute git commands or modify repositories.

faq.question: Can I use this with other issue trackers?
faq.answer: Yes, the skill supports GH-1234, #1234, SENTRY-1234, and LINEAR-ABC-123 formats in issue references.

faq.question: What makes a good commit body?
faq.answer: A good body explains motivation for the change, contrasts with previous behavior when relevant, and uses imperative present tense throughout.
